race.name: Old Fashioned Gravel
race.tagline: Old Fashioned Gravel. 55 miles of gravel through Hokah.

terrain.surface: Gravel roads through Minnesota countryside. Moderate elevation with rolling scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Local Minnesota event. Rolling terrain with moderate access, low costs, and small local field.

biased_opinion.summary: Old Fashioned Gravel is a local event in Minnesota—rolling terrain with moderate elevation. The Minnesota countryside is nice and it's good value, but the small local field and limited organization keep it in Tier 4.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid local Minnesota gravel race. Worth it for Minnesota/Midwest riders. Not worth traveling for.

final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're local to Minnesota—yes, it's good value. If you're traveling—skip it.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better Minnesota races: Almanzo, Dirty Benjamin.

logistics.lodging_strategy: Hokah has limited lodging options. Plan ahead.
logistics.food: Hokah has limited dining options. Stock nutrition.
logistics.camping: Camping available in the pasture (riders could sleep in cars on-site, helpful due to high hotel prices)

non_negotiables.why: Minnesota rolling terrain requires sustained effort.

logistics.explanation: Ian Breitlow, who has "done so many grassroots events in the Midwest," calls this "#1 for quality and hospitality" citing "hot coffee and pastries in the morning" and "super clean, not-porta potty bathrooms." Eric Cleveland noted "Maps were a bit wonky" and Carolyn Franzone got lost on the shake-out ride due to cue sheet errors.

length.explanation: 55 miles sits in that awkward middle distance where it's too short to be epic and too long to be casual. Four route options from 20-100 miles show they're trying to please everyone, which usually means pleasing no one particularly well. At least you can pick your poison. More compact than Grinduro.

technicality.explanation: All routes start with "one mile of paved climb" before reaching gravel on the ridge, then descend the same paved section to finish. Kevin Huang summarized it as "Really mfn hard, really hilly" while Mark Lee noted the 40-mile had "great versatile terrain." The Driftless region delivers rolling hills, farms, and wooded descents. Less technical than The Mid South.

elevation.explanation: 2500 feet over 55 miles averages to manageable suffering in Driftless region terrain. That's enough climbing to respect but not enough to break you, which fits their 'welcoming to novices' positioning. The paved climb start suggests at least one ascent, but this isn't the Rockies. Less climbing than The Mid South.

climate.explanation: Uriah Matznick suffered a mechanical DNF at mile 40 of the 100-mile course, highlighting the self-supported nature where riders must "bring some sort of tire plug, inner tube, and Co2." The race warns "There will not be any mechanical support on the road, you are responsible for arranging a ride if you have issues." More weather exposure than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

altitude.explanation: Southeast Minnesota's Driftless region sits at typical elevations of 800-1400 feet with no altitude training considerations. The paved climb to reach gravel on the ridge represents standard Midwest topography rather than any meaningful elevation challenge. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds — no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: Leslie Johnson enjoyed "a true gravel experience highlighting MN rolling farmland, barns and bluff views" while Jeanne Fricke called it "one of the prettiest rides I've ever done." The Driftless terrain offers "spectacular views" with "wide open to wooded descents" and minimal pavement once riders reach the ridge system.

prestige.explanation: Ryan Greene, who "raced all over this year everything from Midsouth to Montana to Steamboat," noted "the only thing lacking was some organization and that big finish line feel" compared to established events. The race caps at 300 riders and launched in 2024, building grassroots reputation rather than national recognition.

race_quality.explanation: Colin Timm praised the "perfect blend of casual community riding and competitive racing" while Keith Rust would "give it a 10" if the scale went higher than 5. Ryan Greene ranked it among his "fav races of the year" despite noting minor organizational gaps typical of a second-year event finding its footing.

experience.explanation: The farm venue provides a "cool old structure with a rustic feel" barn as event center with post-ride "food, drink, and hangs with new friends." Erin Sullivan appreciated being able to "sleep in my car in the pasture" due to high hotel costs, while Phil Solberg had a "great experience" for his first gravel ride.

community.explanation: Race Director Paul Reardon emphasizes inclusivity: "if you want to come challenge yourself, or just go for a ride with other rad people, make new friends, eat, drink, and laugh, that's what it is all about!" Entry fees support local causes and the event partners with Hokah businesses for food and hydration.

field_depth.explanation: The 100-mile field shows modest competitive depth with winners around 4:44 and mid-pack finishing 2-3 hours later. Brian Werner's enthusiastic but generic review ("the venue was great, the route was great, the vendors were great") reflects a friendly participation-focused field rather than serious racing depth. Thinner field than Ouray Gravel Grinder.

value.explanation: Four distance options, professional timing, food, drinks, and supporting local causes for an undisclosed but presumably reasonable entry fee delivers solid bang for buck. You're getting a organized event experience without the premium pricing of established races. Sometimes being nobody's first choice makes you everybody's good deal.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $50-75. Hokah represents modest Midwest travel costs with car camping available in the farm pasture as Erin Sullivan utilized. Local business partnerships for food and lodging in what organizers call a "super cool little town" keep costs reasonable compared to destination race weekend gouging. Similar expense level to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

2024.conditions: - Historical weather incidents (mud years, heat, wind): Unavailable; event founded in 2024, limited history
key_takeaways: Historical weather incidents (mud years, heat, wind): Unavailable; event founded in 2024, limited history
Race history (founded year, founder if known): New event launched in 2024; no founder named

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

primary.name: Panaracer GravelKing SK
primary.why: Affordable all-rounder. Light knobs add grip without killing speed.

primary.name: Vittoria Terreno Mix
primary.why: Graphene versatility. Mixed-terrain grip with reasonable rolling speed.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners
